tools.name: Compare two commits
tools.description: Compares two commit points (commits, branches, tags, or SHAs) within a repository or across forks, using `BASE...HEAD` or `OWNER:REF...OWNER:REF` format for the `basehead` parameter.

basehead.description: A string specifying the base and head references to compare, in the format `BASE...HEAD`. `BASE` and `HEAD` can be branch names (e.g., `main...develop`), tag names (e.g., `v1.0.0...v1.1.0`), or commit SHA-1s. Both references must exist in the specified repository. To compare branches across forks in the same network, use the format `OWNER:REF...OWNER:REF` (e.g., `octocat:main...another-user:main`).
basehead.title: Basehead

owner.description: The username or organization name that owns the repository. This field is not case-sensitive.
owner.title: Owner

page.description: Page number of the results to fetch, for pagination when the number of differences (commits or files) is large.
page.title: Page

per_page.description: Number of results (e.g., files or commits) to return per page, with a maximum of 100, for pagination.
per_page.title: Per Page

repo.description: The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This field is not case-sensitive.
repo.title: Repo

inputParameters.title: CompareTwoCommitsRequest
inputParameters.description: Request schema for `CompareTwoCommits` action. Specifies the repository and the two commit points (base and head) to compare.

data.description: A dictionary containing the comparison details. This typically includes: the status of the comparison (e.g., 'diverged', 'ahead', 'behind', 'identical'), the number of commits `ahead_by` and `behind_by` the base, `total_commits` in the range, an array of `commits` objects, an array of `files` objects detailing changed files (including status, additions, deletions, changes, patch, etc.), and various URLs (`html_url`, `permalink_url`, `diff_url`, `patch_url`) for accessing the comparison.
data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

tools.name: Create a check run
tools.description: Creates a new check run for a specific commit in a repository, used by external services to report status, detailed feedback, annotations, and images directly within the GitHub UI.

actions.description: A list of up to three action objects defining interactive buttons displayed on GitHub after the check run completes. Each object needs a `label` (button text), `identifier` (unique ID for the action), and `description` (tooltip). Clicking a button sends a `check_run.requested_action` webhook to your app.
actions.title: Actions

items.description: Model for a check run action.
items.title: CheckRunAction

description.description: A short explanation of what this action would do (max 40 characters).
description.title: Description

identifier.description: A reference for the action on the integrator's system (max 20 characters).
identifier.title: Identifier

label.description: The text to be displayed on a button in the web UI (max 20 characters).
label.title: Label

completed_at.description: The ISO 8601 timestamp (YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ) indicating when the check run finished. **Required if `status` is `completed`**.
completed_at.title: Completed At

conclusion.description: **Required if `completed_at` is provided or if `status` is `completed`**. Specifies the final outcome of the check (e.g., 'success', 'failure'). Note: Setting `conclusion` automatically sets `status` to `completed`. GitHub alone can set a conclusion to `stale`.
conclusion.title: Conclusion

details_url.description: The URL of the integrator's site providing full details of the check. If omitted, the GitHub App's homepage is used. This URL is available from the check's UI.
details_url.title: Details Url

external_id.description: A unique identifier for the check run on the integrator's system. This helps in correlating check runs between GitHub and the external system.
external_id.title: External Id

head_sha.description: The SHA of the commit for which the check run is created.
head_sha.title: Head Sha

name.description: The name of the check to be displayed in the GitHub UI. For example, "Code Coverage" or "Linter".
name.title: Name

output__annotations.description: A list of annotation objects detailing issues at specific code locations. Annotations are visible in the 'Checks' and 'Files changed' tabs of a pull request. Each annotation object should specify `path`, `start_line`, `end_line`, `annotation_level` ('notice', 'warning', or 'failure'), and `message`. Optional fields include `start_column`, `end_column`, `title`, and `raw_details`. Up to 50 annotations per API request; for more, use subsequent 'Update a check run' calls. GitHub Actions limits are 10 warnings and 10 errors per step.
output__annotations.title: Output  Annotations

items.description: Model for a check run annotation.
items.title: CheckRunAnnotation

annotation_level.description: The level of the annotation (notice, warning, or failure).
annotation_level.title: Annotation Level

end_column.description: The end column of the annotation. Annotations only support start_column and end_column on the same line.
end_column.title: End Column

end_line.description: The end line of the annotation.
end_line.title: End Line

message.description: A short description of the feedback for these lines of code.
message.title: Message

path.description: The path of the file to add an annotation to.
path.title: Path

start_column.description: The start column of the annotation. Annotations only support start_column and end_column on the same line.
start_column.title: Start Column

start_line.description: The start line of the annotation.
start_line.title: Start Line

title.description: The title that represents the annotation.
title.title: Title

output__images.description: A list of image objects to display in the check run's output in the GitHub UI. Each object requires `alt` (alternative text), `image_url` (URL of the image), and an optional `caption`.
output__images.title: Output  Images

items.description: Model for a check run image.
items.title: CheckRunImage

alt.description: The alternative text for the image.
alt.title: Alt

image_url.description: The full URL of the image.
image_url.title: Image Url

output__summary.description: A summary of the check run's findings. Supports Markdown. **Maximum length**: 65,535 characters.
output__summary.title: Output  Summary

output__text.description: Detailed textual information about the check run's output. Supports Markdown. **Maximum length**: 65,535 characters.
output__text.title: Output  Text

output__title.description: A descriptive title for the output of the check run, displayed in the GitHub UI. For example, 'Linter Scan Summary'.
output__title.title: Output  Title

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. This name is not case sensitive.
owner.title: Owner

repo.description: The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This name is not case sensitive.
repo.title: Repo

started_at.description: The ISO 8601 timestamp (YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ) indicating when the check run began.
started_at.title: Started At

status.description: The current status of the check run. Only GitHub Actions can set `status` to `waiting`, `pending`, or `requested`.
status.title: Status

This action allows users to set up a development environment quickly by creating a codespace from a specified repository or pull request.

inputParameters.title: CreateACodespaceForTheAuthenticatedUserRequest

Request body for POST /user/codespaces.

Provide either:
- repository_id (int) + ref (string branch/commit/PR ref), or
- pull_request object with pull_request_number (int) and repository_id (int).

Other optional fields supported by the API (machine, location, devcontainer_path, etc.) can be added later if needed.

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action

tools.name: Create a codespace from a pull request
tools.description: Creates a GitHub Codespace for an open pull request in a Codespaces-enabled repository, with options to customize its configuration.

client_ip.description: Client's public IP address for location auto-detection if proxied and `geo` or `location` are not specified.
client_ip.title: Client Ip

devcontainer_path.description: Path to a `devcontainer.json` file in the repository that defines the development environment.
devcontainer_path.title: Devcontainer Path

geo.description: Geographic area for this codespace (e.g., `UsEast`, `EuropeWest`); supersedes `location`. If unspecified, typically IP-derived.
geo.title: Geo

idle_timeout_minutes.description: Minutes of inactivity after which the codespace is automatically stopped. A default timeout applies if unspecified.
idle_timeout_minutes.title: Idle Timeout Minutes

location.description: Requested geographic location (e.g., `EastUs`, `WestEurope`). This parameter is deprecated; use `geo`. If unspecified, location may be IP-derived.
location.title: Location

machine.description: Machine type for this codespace (e.g., `standardLinux`). Varies by CPU, RAM, storage. Uses default if unspecified.
machine.title: Machine

multi_repo_permissions_opt_out.description: Set to `true` to prevent GitHub from requesting additional repository permissions defined in `devcontainer.json`. Defaults to `false` (permissions will be requested).
multi_repo_permissions_opt_out.title: Multi Repo Permissions Opt Out

owner.description: The username of the account that owns the repository. This is case-insensitive.
owner.title: Owner

pull_number.description: The unique number identifying the pull request.
pull_number.title: Pull Number

repo.description: The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This is case-insensitive.
repo.title: Repo

retention_period_minutes.description: Retention period in minutes (0-43200, i.e., up to 30 days) for a stopped codespace. 0 means immediate deletion.
retention_period_minutes.title: Retention Period Minutes

working_directory.description: Working directory for the codespace upon opening. Defaults to the repository root if unspecified.
working_directory.title: Working Directory

tools.name: Create a codespace in a repository

client_ip.description: IP address to infer preferred region if `location` and `geo` are unspecified; useful for proxied requests.
client_ip.title: Client Ip

devcontainer_path.description: Path to a `devcontainer.json` in the repository; uses `.devcontainer/devcontainer.json` or `devcontainer.json` at root if not specified.
devcontainer_path.title: Devcontainer Path

display_name.description: Custom display name for the codespace; a default name is generated if not provided.
display_name.title: Display Name

geo.description: Geographic area for the codespace, replacing `location`; determined by user IP if not specified.
geo.title: Geo

idle_timeout_minutes.description: Minutes of inactivity before codespace auto-stops; uses a default timeout if not specified.
idle_timeout_minutes.title: Idle Timeout Minutes

location.description: Requested AWS region (best-effort, may differ); determined by user IP if not provided. Deprecated: use `geo`.
location.title: Location

machine.description: Machine type (CPU, RAM, storage). See 'List available machine types for a repository' action for options; uses a default type if not specified.
machine.title: Machine

multi_repo_permissions_opt_out.description: If `true`, opts out of granting multi-repository permissions from `devcontainer.json`. If unspecified or `false`, permissions are granted if requested.
multi_repo_permissions_opt_out.title: Multi Repo Permissions Opt Out

owner.description: Username or organization name owning the repository; not case-sensitive.
owner.title: Owner

ref.description: Git reference (e.g., branch name) for the codespace; uses repository's default branch if not provided.
ref.title: Ref

repo.description: Name of the repository, without the `.git` extension; not case-sensitive.
repo.title: Repo

retention_period_minutes.description: Minutes an idle (stopped) codespace is retained before auto-deletion (0-43200, i.e., up to 30 days); uses a default period if not specified.
retention_period_minutes.title: Retention Period Minutes

working_directory.description: Directory to use as default when codespace opens; uses repository root if not specified.
working_directory.title: Working Directory

color.description: The hexadecimal color code for the label (e.g., `f29513`), without the leading `#`. If not provided, GitHub will assign a random color.
color.title: Color

description.description: A short description of the label. Maximum 100 characters.
description.title: Description

name.description: The name of the label. Emoji can be added to label names, using either native emoji or colon-style markup. For example, typing `:strawberry:` will render the emoji ![:strawberry:](https://github.githubassets.com/images/icons/emoji/unicode/1f353.png ":strawberry:"). For a full list of available emoji and codes, see the "[Emoji cheat sheet](https://github.com/ikatyang/emoji-cheat-sheet)."
name.title: Name

owner.description: The username of the account that owns the repository. This is not case sensitive.
owner.title: Owner

repo.description: The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This is not case sensitive.
repo.title: Repo

inputParameters.title: CreateALabelRequest
inputParameters.description: Request schema for creating a new label in a GitHub repository.

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

tools.name: Create a milestone
tools.description: Creates a milestone in a GitHub repository for tracking progress on issues or pull requests; requires repository existence and user write permissions.

description.description: Detailed description of the milestone.
description.title: Description
examples: Tracking all issues and PRs for the upcoming v1.0 release.
Tasks for the third quarter sprint.

due_on.description: Due date for the milestone (ISO 8601 format: `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`).
due_on.title: Due On

owner.description: Username of the repository owner (case-insensitive).
owner.title: Owner

repo.description: Repository name, without the `.git` extension (case-insensitive).
repo.title: Repo

inputParameters.title: CreateAMilestoneRequest
inputParameters.description: Request to create a milestone in a GitHub repository.

data.description: Details of the newly created milestone from the GitHub API.
data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

tools.name: Create an autolink reference for a repository
tools.description: Creates a repository autolink to automatically convert text references (e.g., 'TICKET-123') into hyperlinks, using a unique `key_prefix` and a `url_template` that includes `<num>`.

is_alphanumeric.description: Specifies if the `<num>` placeholder in `url_template` matches alphanumeric characters (`A-Z` (case-insensitive), `0-9`, and `-`) or only numeric characters (`0-9`).
is_alphanumeric.title: Is Alphanumeric

key_prefix.description: Prefix that triggers the autolink (e.g., 'JIRA-'). When followed by an identifier, it's converted into a link. Must be non-empty and not contain spaces.
key_prefix.title: Key Prefix

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. This can be a username or an organization name. The name is not case-sensitive.
owner.title: Owner

repo.description: The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. The name is not case-sensitive.
repo.title: Repo

url_template.description: URL template for the autolink, using `<num>` as a placeholder for the reference identifier (e.g., 'https://example.atlassian.net/browse/<num>'). Behavior of `<num>` is determined by `is_alphanumeric`.
url_template.title: Url Template

inputParameters.title: CreateAnAutolinkReferenceForARepositoryRequest
inputParameters.description: Request schema for creating an autolink reference in a repository.

data.description: A dictionary representing the autolink reference object that was created. This typically includes fields such as `id`, `key_prefix`, `url_template`, and `is_alphanumeric`.
data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

tools.name: Create an environment variable
tools.description: Creates an encrypted environment variable for a pre-existing environment within a GitHub repository; will fail if the variable name already exists.

environment_name.description: The name of the environment for which to create the variable. The name must be URL encoded if it contains special characters (e.g., slashes `/` must be replaced with `%2F`).
environment_name.title: Environment Name

name.description: The name of the environment variable to create (e.g., `API_KEY`).
name.title: Name

owner.description: The username or organization name that owns the repository. This field is not case-sensitive.
owner.title: Owner

repo.description: The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This field is not case-sensitive.
repo.title: Repo

value.description: The value of the environment variable (e.g., `your_secret_token`). This value will be encrypted.
value.title: Value

inputParameters.title: CreateAnEnvironmentVariableRequest
inputParameters.description: Request schema for creating a new environment variable in a repository's environment.

data.description: An empty dictionary is returned upon successful creation of the environment variable (HTTP 201 Created).
data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

tools.name: Create an issue
tools.description: Creates a new issue in a GitHub repository, requiring the repository to exist and have issues enabled; specific fields like assignees, milestone, or labels may require push access.

assignee.description: Login for the user to whom this issue should be assigned. NOTE: Only users with push access can set the assignee; it is silently dropped otherwise. **This field is deprecated in favor of `assignees`.**
assignee.title: Assignee

assignees.description: GitHub login names for users to assign to this issue. NOTE: Only users with push access can set assignees; they are silently dropped otherwise.
assignees.title: Assignees

body.description: The detailed textual contents of the new issue.
body.title: Body
examples: Detailed description of the bug with steps to reproduce.
I think adding a dark mode would improve user experience...

labels.description: Array of label names to associate with this issue (generally case-insensitive). NOTE: Only users with push access can set labels; they are silently dropped otherwise. Pass an empty list to clear all labels.
labels.title: Labels

milestone.description: The ID of the milestone to associate this issue with (e.g., "5"). NOTE: Only users with push access can set the milestone; it is silently dropped otherwise.
milestone.title: Milestone

owner.description: The GitHub account owner of the repository (case-insensitive).
owner.title: Owner

repo.description: The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension (case-insensitive).
repo.title: Repo

title.description: The title for the new issue.
title.title: Title

inputParameters.title: CreateAnIssueRequest
inputParameters.description: Request schema for creating a new issue in a GitHub repository.

data.description: A dictionary containing the full data representation of the newly created GitHub issue, including its ID, title, body, state, assignees, labels, etc.
data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

body.description: Comment content in GitHub Flavored Markdown.

issue_number.description: Number identifying the issue or pull request for the comment.
issue_number.title: Issue Number

owner.description: Account owner of the repository (username or organization); not case-sensitive.
owner.title: Owner

repo.description: Name of the repository (without `.git` extension); not case-sensitive.
repo.title: Repo

inputParameters.title: CreateAnIssueCommentRequest
inputParameters.description: Parameters to create a comment on a GitHub issue or pull request.

data.description: Full API response for the created issue comment, including ID, author, body, and timestamps.
data.title: Data

error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

Detailed plan and discussion for the website redesign project.

tools.name: Create an organization repository
tools.description: Creates a new repository within a specified GitHub organization, with options for detailed configuration including visibility, features, merge strategies, initial commit, and templates.

allow_merge_commit.description: Allow merging pull requests with a merge commit.
allow_merge_commit.title: Allow Merge Commit

auto_init.description: Create an initial commit with an empty README.
auto_init.title: Auto Init

custom_properties.description: JSON string containing custom properties for the repository as a key-value object. Example: '{"project_lead": "octocat", "status": "alpha"}'
custom_properties.title: Custom Properties

delete_branch_on_merge.description: Automatically delete head branches when pull requests are merged. Requires organization owner privileges if true.
delete_branch_on_merge.title: Delete Branch On Merge

description.description: Short description of the repository.
description.title: Description
examples: A project to demonstrate awesome capabilities.

gitignore_template.description: Name of the .gitignore template to apply (e.g., "Python", "Node"). Refer to the [GitHub gitignore template list](https://github.com/github/gitignore).
gitignore_template.title: Gitignore Template

has_projects.description: Enable projects for this repository. Fails if organization has disabled repository projects and this is true.
has_projects.title: Has Projects

is_template.description: Make this repository a template repository.
is_template.title: Is Template

license_template.description: License template keyword (e.g., "mit", "apache-2.0"). See [GitHub license documentation](https://docs.github.com/articles/licensing-a-repository/#searching-github-by-license-type) for options.
license_template.title: License Template

merge_commit_message.description: Default message for merge commits: 'PR_TITLE', 'PR_BODY', or 'BLANK'.
merge_commit_message.title: Merge Commit Message

merge_commit_title.description: Default title for merge commits: 'PR_TITLE' or 'MERGE_MESSAGE'.
merge_commit_title.title: Merge Commit Title

name.description: Name of the new repository.
name.title: Name

org.description: Name of the organization where the repository will be created (case-insensitive).
org.title: Org

private.description: Whether the repository is private. `visibility` takes precedence if both are set.
private.title: Private

squash_merge_commit_message.description: Default message for squash merge commits: 'PR_BODY', 'COMMIT_MESSAGES', or 'BLANK'.
squash_merge_commit_message.title: Squash Merge Commit Message

squash_merge_commit_title.description: Default title for squash merge commits: 'PR_TITLE' or 'COMMIT_OR_PR_TITLE'.
squash_merge_commit_title.title: Squash Merge Commit Title

team_id.description: ID of the team to grant access to this repository within the organization.
team_id.title: Team Id

use_squash_pr_title_as_default.description: DEPRECATED: Use `squash_merge_commit_title`. Default to pull request title for squash-merge commits.
use_squash_pr_title_as_default.title: Use Squash Pr Title As Default

visibility.description: Repository visibility: 'public' (visible to everyone) or 'private' (visible to collaborators).
visibility.title: Visibility

inputParameters.title: CreateAnOrganizationRepositoryRequest
inputParameters.description: Request schema for creating a new repository in a GitHub organization.

data.description: A dictionary containing the full representation of the newly created repository.
data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

tools.name: Create an organization variable
tools.description: Creates a new, uniquely named GitHub Actions variable for an organization, with configurable repository access visibility (all, private, or selected).

name.description: The name of the organization variable. Must be unique at the organization level.
name.title: Name

org.description: The name of the GitHub organization. This name is not case-sensitive.
org.title: Org

selected_repository_ids.description: A list of repository integer IDs that can access this organization variable. This field is required and only applicable when `visibility` is set to 'selected'.
selected_repository_ids.title: Selected Repository Ids

value.description: The value of the organization variable.
value.title: Value

visibility.description: Controls which repositories in the organization can access the variable. Accepted values are 'all' (all repositories), 'private' (only private repositories), or 'selected' (specific repositories designated by `selected_repository_ids`).
visibility.title: Visibility

inputParameters.title: CreateAnOrganizationVariableRequest
inputParameters.description: Request schema for `CreateAnOrganizationVariable`

data.description: An empty dictionary indicating the successful creation of the organization variable, as the GitHub API typically returns an empty body (201 Created) for this operation.
data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

tools.name: Create an organization webhook
tools.description: Creates a webhook for a GitHub organization to deliver event notifications to a configured URL.

active.description: Boolean indicating if the webhook is active. `true` sends notifications, `false` does not. Defaults to `true`.
active.title: Active

config__content__type.description: The media type for serializing webhook payloads. Supported: `json`, `form`. GitHub API defaults to `form` if this field is not set or is `None`.
config__content__type.title: Config  Content  Type

config__insecure__ssl.description: Controls SSL certificate verification for `config_url`. '1' disables verification (not recommended), '0' enables. GitHub API defaults to '0' (verification enabled) if this field is not set or is `None`.
config__insecure__ssl.title: Config  Insecure  Ssl

config__password.description: Password for basic authentication if the webhook endpoint (`config_url`) requires it, corresponding to `config_username`.
config__password.title: Config  Password

config__secret.description: Optional secret for generating an HMAC hex digest for payload verification (X-Hub-Signature-256 header). If provided, this is used as the key.
config__secret.title: Config  Secret

config__url.description: The target URL for webhook payload delivery. This URL is a mandatory part of the webhook's `config` object and will receive POST requests for subscribed events.
config__url.title: Config  Url

config__username.description: Username for basic authentication if the webhook endpoint (`config_url`) requires it. Use only if your endpoint is protected by basic auth.
config__username.title: Config  Username

events.description: List of event names to trigger the webhook. Use `['*']` for all events. Defaults to `['push']` if not specified. See GitHub docs for event types.
events.title: Events

name.description: The name of the webhook. Must be "web" for organization webhooks.
name.title: Name

org.description: The name of the GitHub organization. This name is not case-sensitive.
org.title: Org

inputParameters.title: CreateAnOrganizationWebhookRequest
inputParameters.description: Request schema for `CreateAnOrganizationWebhook`

data.description: A dictionary containing the complete JSON representation of the created webhook object as returned by the GitHub API.
data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

tools.name: Create a project card
tools.description: Creates a project card in a GitHub project column; the request body must contain either a `note` for a note-only card, or both `content_id` (ID of an issue or pull request) and `content_type` (e.g., 'Issue', 'PullRequest'). This action facilitates the organization of tasks and issues in a project management context within GitHub.

column_id.description: The unique identifier of the project column where the card will be created. This value is used as a path parameter in the API request URL (e.g., `/projects/columns/{column_id}/cards`).
column_id.title: Column Id

inputParameters.title: CreateAProjectCardRequest
inputParameters.description: Defines the `column_id` path parameter for creating a GitHub project card. The actual card content (e.g., `note` or `content_id`/`content_type`) must be provided separately in the request body.

data.description: A dictionary containing the full representation of the newly created project card, as returned by the GitHub API.
data.title: Data

successful.title: Successful

tools.name: Create a pull request
tools.description: Creates a pull request in a GitHub repository, requiring existing `base` and `head` branches; `title` or `issue` must be provided.

base.description: The name of the branch you want the changes pulled into. This must be an existing branch on the current (target) repository. You cannot submit a pull request to one repository that requests a merge to a base branch of another repository.
base.title: Base

body.description: The detailed description or contents of the pull request.
body.title: Body
examples: This PR introduces a new feature that does X, Y, and Z.
Fixes #42 by addressing the off-by-one error.

draft.description: Indicates whether the pull request should be created as a draft. Draft pull requests cannot be merged until marked as ready for review.
draft.title: Draft

head.description: The name of the branch where your changes are implemented. For cross-repository pull requests, namespace `head` with the source owner and branch, like `username:branch`.
head.title: Head

head_repo.description: The name of the repository (e.g., 'octocat/Hello-World') where the changes in the pull request were made. This field is required for cross-repository pull requests if both the source and target repositories are owned by the same organization but are different repositories.
head_repo.title: Head Repo

issue.description: The number of an existing issue in the repository to convert into a pull request. If provided, the issue's title and body may be used for the pull request. Required if `title` is not specified.
issue.title: Issue

maintainer_can_modify.description: Indicates whether maintainers of the upstream repository can modify the pull request. This is primarily relevant for pull requests originating from forks.
maintainer_can_modify.title: Maintainer Can Modify

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. This name is not case-sensitive.
owner.title: Owner

repo.description: The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This name is not case-sensitive.
repo.title: Repo

title.description: The title of the new pull request. Required unless `issue` is specified.
title.title: Title

inputParameters.title: CreateAPullRequestRequest
inputParameters.description: Request schema for `CreateAPullRequest`

data.description: A dictionary containing the full representation of the created pull request.
data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

repo.description: The name of the repository without the `.git` extension. The name is not case sensitive.

sha.description: SHA-1 hash of an existing commit in the repository that the new reference will point to.
sha.title: Sha

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

tools.name: Create a release
tools.description: Creates a release in a GitHub repository for a specified tag; the tag must be unique for published releases, and if a `discussion_category_name` is given, it must already exist.

body.description: A detailed description of the release. Markdown formatting is supported.
body.title: Body
examples: This release includes new features X, Y, and bug fixes for Z.

# New Features
- Feature A
- Feature B

discussion_category_name.description: If specified, a new discussion will be created in this category and linked to the release. The category must already exist in the repository's discussions.
discussion_category_name.title: Discussion Category Name

draft.description: Set to `true` to create an unpublished (draft) release. Defaults to `false`.
draft.title: Draft

generate_release_notes.description: Set to `true` to automatically generate the release title (`name`) and description (`body`) from the commit history since the last release. Defaults to `false`.
generate_release_notes.title: Generate Release Notes

make_latest.description: Specifies if this release should be marked as the latest for the repository. Valid values: 'true', 'false', 'legacy'. Defaults to 'true'. Draft releases and prereleases cannot be set as 'latest'.
make_latest.title: Make Latest

name.description: The title of the release. If omitted and `generate_release_notes` is false, it defaults to the `tag_name`.
name.title: Name

owner.description: The account owner of the repository (username or organization name). This field is not case-sensitive.
owner.title: Owner

prerelease.description: Set to `true` to identify this release as a pre-release. Defaults to `false`.
prerelease.title: Prerelease

repo.description: The name of the repository, without the .git extension. This field is not case-sensitive.
repo.title: Repo

tag_name.description: The name of the tag for this release. This tag must be unique for published releases.
tag_name.title: Tag Name

target_commitish.description: Specifies the commitish value (e.g., branch name, tag name, or commit SHA) from which the Git tag is created. Defaults to the repository's default branch if the tag specified in `tag_name` doesn't exist yet.
target_commitish.title: Target Commitish

data.description: Data from the action execution
data.title: Data

assets.description: A list of assets attached to this release.
assets.title: Assets

browser_download_url.description: The direct URL for downloading this asset via a web browser.
browser_download_url.title: Browser Download Url

content_type.description: The MIME type of the asset (e.g., 'application/zip', 'image/png').
content_type.title: Content Type

created_at.description: The ISO 8601 timestamp for when the asset was created.
created_at.title: Created At

download_count.description: The number of times this asset has been downloaded.
download_count.title: Download Count

id.description: The unique numerical identifier for this release asset.
id.title: Id

label.description: An optional, short, descriptive label for the asset.
label.title: Label

name.description: The filename of the release asset.
name.title: Name

node_id.description: The global Relay ID for this release asset.
node_id.title: Node Id

size.description: The size of the asset in bytes.
size.title: Size

state.description: The state of the release asset. Typically 'uploaded' for successfully uploaded assets.
state.title: State

updated_at.description: The ISO 8601 timestamp for when the asset was last updated.
updated_at.title: Updated At

uploader.description: Information about the user who uploaded a release asset. Inherits fields from ReleaseAuthor.
uploader.title: ReleaseAssetUploader

avatar_url.description: The URL for the user's avatar image.
avatar_url.title: Avatar Url

email.description: The publicly visible email address of the user. May be null.
email.title: Email

events_url.description: The API URL for the user's public events. Placeholder {/privacy} may be present.
events_url.title: Events Url

followers_url.description: The API URL for listing the user's followers.
followers_url.title: Followers Url

following_url.description: The API URL for listing users followed by this user. Placeholder {/other_user} may be present.
following_url.title: Following Url

gists_url.description: The API URL for the user's gists. Placeholder {/gist_id} may be present.
gists_url.title: Gists Url

gravatar_id.description: The Gravatar ID for the user. May be empty if the user does not use Gravatar.
gravatar_id.title: Gravatar Id

html_url.description: The URL to the user's profile page on GitHub.
html_url.title: Html Url

id.description: The unique numerical identifier for the user on GitHub.
id.title: Id

login.description: The GitHub username (login) of the user.
login.title: Login

name.description: The display name of the user. May be null.
name.title: Name

node_id.description: The global Relay ID for the user, used with GraphQL API.
node_id.title: Node Id

organizations_url.description: The API URL for the user's organization memberships.
organizations_url.title: Organizations Url

received_events_url.description: The API URL for events received by the user.
received_events_url.title: Received Events Url

repos_url.description: The API URL for the user's public repositories.
repos_url.title: Repos Url

site_admin.description: Indicates whether the user is a GitHub site administrator.
site_admin.title: Site Admin

starred_at.description: Timestamp indicating when the user performed a starring action related to a repository, if available in the context of this user object.
starred_at.title: Starred At

starred_url.description: The API URL for repositories starred by this user. Placeholders {/owner}{/repo} may be present.
starred_url.title: Starred Url

subscriptions_url.description: The API URL for the user's repository subscriptions.
subscriptions_url.title: Subscriptions Url

url.description: The API URL for this user's details.
url.title: Url

user_view_type.description: A string indicating the user's view type; its meaning might be context-dependent.
user_view_type.title: User View Type

url.description: The API URL for this release asset.
url.title: Url

assets_url.description: The API URL for accessing the assets associated with this release.
assets_url.title: Assets Url

author.description: The GitHub user who created the release.
author.title: ReleaseAuthor

avatar_url.description: The URL for the user's avatar image.
avatar_url.title: Avatar Url

reactions.description: A summary of reactions (e.g., thumbs up, heart) to this release.

total_count.description: The total number of reactions on the release.

tag_name.description: The name of the tag associated with this release.

target_commitish.description: The commitish value (e.g., branch name or commit SHA) that this release's tag was created from.

Optionally, specify `line` (or `start_line` for multi-line), and `side` (or `start_side`) for diff location. `position` is deprecated; use `line`. Example: `[{'path': 'file.py', 'line': 10, 'body': 'Refactor this.'}]`

client_id.description: Client ID of the GitHub App.

permissions__actions.description: Permission for GitHub Actions workflows, workflow runs, and artifacts. Applies to target repositories.
permissions__actions.title: Permissions  Actions

permissions__administration.description: Permission for repository administration (settings, teams, collaborators). Applies to target repositories.
permissions__administration.title: Permissions  Administration

permissions__checks.description: Permission for checks on code (e.g., CI statuses). Applies to target repositories.
permissions__checks.title: Permissions  Checks

permissions__codespaces.description: Permission for Codespaces. Applies to target user/organization if repositories are not specified, otherwise to target repositories.
permissions__codespaces.title: Permissions  Codespaces

permissions__contents.description: Permission for repository contents, commits, branches, downloads, releases, and merges. Applies to target repositories.
permissions__contents.title: Permissions  Contents

permissions__dependabot__secrets.description: Permission for Dependabot secrets for targeted repositories.
permissions__dependabot__secrets.title: Permissions  Dependabot  Secrets

permissions__deployments.description: Permission for deployments and deployment statuses. Applies to target repositories.
permissions__deployments.title: Permissions  Deployments

permissions__email__addresses.description: Permission to manage email addresses for the user account. Applies to target user.
permissions__email__addresses.title: Permissions  Email  Addresses

permissions__environments.description: Permission for repository environments. Applies to target repositories.
permissions__environments.title: Permissions  Environments

permissions__followers.description: Permission to manage followers for the user account. Applies to target user.
permissions__followers.title: Permissions  Followers

permissions__git__ssh__keys.description: Permission to manage Git SSH keys for the user account. Applies to target user.
permissions__git__ssh__keys.title: Permissions  Git  Ssh  Keys

permissions__gpg__keys.description: Permission to view and manage GPG keys for the user account. Applies to target user.
permissions__gpg__keys.title: Permissions  Gpg  Keys

permissions__interaction__limits.description: Permission to view and manage interaction limits on a repository. Applies to target repositories or organization.
permissions__interaction__limits.title: Permissions  Interaction  Limits

permissions__issues.description: Permission for issues, comments, assignees, labels, and milestones. Applies to target repositories.
permissions__issues.title: Permissions  Issues

permissions__members.description: Permission for organization members and teams. Applies to target organization.
permissions__members.title: Permissions  Members

permissions__metadata.description: Read-only permission for repository metadata, search, and collaborator listing. Applies to target repositories.
permissions__metadata.title: Permissions  Metadata

tools.name: Create a dependency snapshot
tools.description: Creates a snapshot of a repository's dependencies to populate the GitHub dependency graph and enable security alerts; `sha` must be a 40-character commit ID, `ref` a fully qualified Git reference (e.g., `refs/heads/main`), and `scanned` an ISO 8601 timestamp.

detector__name.description: Optional name of the tool used to detect dependencies.
detector__name.title: Detector  Name

detector__url.description: Optional URL of the detector tool used.
detector__url.title: Detector  Url

detector__version.description: Optional version of the detector tool used.
detector__version.title: Detector  Version

job__correlator.description: Optional string to group snapshots. For a given `job.correlator` and `detector.name`, only the 'latest' snapshot is current. Useful to distinguish detection runs (e.g., concatenating GITHUB_WORKFLOW and GITHUB_JOB).
job__correlator.title: Job  Correlator

job__html__url.description: Optional URL for the job that generated this snapshot.
job__html__url.title: Job  Html  Url

job__id.description: Optional external ID of the job that generated this snapshot.
job__id.title: Job  Id

manifests.description: Optional collection of package manifests as a JSON string (e.g., package-lock.json, pom.xml). Keys are manifest file names; values detail dependencies. Example: '{"package-lock.json": {"name": "...", "resolved": {...}}}'
manifests.title: Manifests

metadata.description: Optional user-defined metadata as a JSON string for domain-specific information. Limited to 8 keys with scalar values (e.g., string, number, boolean). Example: '{"key1": "value1", "key2": 123}'
metadata.title: Metadata

owner.description: Account owner of the repository (name is not case-sensitive).
owner.title: Owner

ref.description: Git reference (fully qualified, e.g., `refs/heads/main`) of the repository branch/tag that triggered this snapshot.
ref.title: Ref

repo.description: Repository name, without `.git` extension (name is not case-sensitive).
repo.title: Repo

scanned.description: UTC timestamp (ISO 8601 format: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ) when the snapshot was taken.
scanned.title: Scanned

sha.description: Commit SHA (maximum 40 characters) associated with this dependency snapshot.
sha.title: Sha

version.description: Version of the dependency snapshot submission, typically of the manifest or lock file format.
version.title: Version

inputParameters.title: CreateASnapshotOfDependenciesForARepositoryRequest
inputParameters.description: Input for creating a dependency snapshot, capturing the repository's dependency state at a specific commit.

data.description: ID of the created snapshot and a confirmation message.
data.title: Data

error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

tools.name: Create a tree
tools.description: Creates a new Git tree object in a repository, defining file/directory structure by specifying tree entries, optionally building on a `base_tree` SHA; all provided SHAs must be valid.

base_tree.description: SHA1 of an existing Git tree object to use as a base. If provided, its entries are combined with `tree` entries, where `tree` entries overwrite those from `base_tree` with the same path. Typically the SHA1 of the latest commit's tree for new branch changes. If omitted, the new tree is built from `tree` entries; files from the parent commit's tree not in `tree` are treated as deleted.
base_tree.title: Base Tree

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.
owner.title: Owner

repo.description: The name of the repository without the `.git` extension. The name is not case sensitive.
repo.title: Repo

tree.description: Array of objects defining the tree structure. Each object (node) requires `path` (string), `mode` (string; e.g., '100644' file, '100755' executable, '040000' subdirectory/tree, '160000' submodule, '120000' symlink), and `type` (string: 'blob', 'tree', or 'commit'). For new/updated blobs, provide `content` (UTF-8 string). For existing objects or `tree`/`commit` types, provide `sha` (string). To delete, specify `path`, `mode`, `type`, and set `sha` to `null`.
tree.title: Tree

inputParameters.title: CreateATreeRequest
inputParameters.description: Request schema for `CreateATree`

data.description: A dictionary representing the created Git tree object. It includes the `sha` and `url` of the new tree, an array of `tree` items (nodes in the tree), and a `truncated` boolean flag indicating if the number of items in the tree array exceeded the maximum limit and was cut short.
data.title: Data

error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

By providing the encrypted value alongside the key ID, you can seamlessly maintain the necessary credentials for your repository's operations.

tools.name: Generate release notes content for a release
tools.description: Generates Markdown release notes content (listing changes, pull requests, and contributors) for a GitHub repository release, customizable via tags and a configuration file.

configuration_file_path.description: Specifies a path to a configuration file in the repository (e.g., `.github/release.yml`) containing settings for generating release notes. If unspecified, GitHub looks for a configuration file at ".github/release.yml" or ".github/release.yaml". If no such file is found, default settings are used.
configuration_file_path.title: Configuration File Path

owner.description: The username or organization name that owns the repository. This field is not case-sensitive.
owner.title: Owner

previous_tag_name.description: The name of the previous tag to use as the starting point for the release notes. This manually specifies the range of changes to be included. If omitted, GitHub will attempt to automatically determine the previous release.
previous_tag_name.title: Previous Tag Name

repo.description: The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This field is not case-sensitive.
repo.title: Repo

tag_name.description: The tag name for which the release notes are to be generated. This can be an existing tag or a new tag name.
tag_name.title: Tag Name

target_commitish.description: Specifies the commitish value (e.g., a branch name, tag name, or commit SHA) that will be the target for the release's tag. This is required if the `tag_name` does not reference an existing tag. It is ignored if `tag_name` already exists.
target_commitish.title: Target Commitish

inputParameters.title: GenerateReleaseNotesContentForAReleaseRequest
inputParameters.description: Request schema for generating release notes content for a GitHub release.

data.description: A dictionary containing the generated release notes. Expected keys are 'name' (the title of the release notes) and 'body' (the Markdown content of the release notes).
data.title: Data

examples.body:
## Changes
- Fix for bug #123
- New feature X

## Contributors
- @user1

tools.name: Get a commit
tools.description: Retrieves a specific commit from a repository by its owner, name, and a valid commit reference (SHA, branch, or tag), supporting pagination for large diffs.

owner.description: The username or organization name that owns the repository. This field is not case-sensitive.
owner.title: Owner

page.description: Page number for paginating the commit's diff if it's too large. For more information, see "[Using pagination in the REST API](https://docs.github.com/rest/using-the-rest-api/using-pagination-in-the-rest-api)."
page.title: Page

per_page.description: Number of results per page when paginating the commit's diff (max 100). For more information, see "[Using pagination in the REST API](https://docs.github.com/rest/using-the-rest-api/using-pagination-in-the-rest-api)."
per_page.title: Per Page

ref.description: The commit reference. Can be a commit SHA (e.g., '`sha`'), a branch name (e.g., 'heads/`BRANCH_NAME`' or simply '`BRANCH_NAME`'), or a tag name (e.g., 'tags/`TAG_NAME`'). For more information, see "[Git References](https://git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Git-Internals-Git-References)" in the Git documentation.
ref.title: Ref

repo.description: The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This field is not case-sensitive.

tools.name: Get a diff of the dependencies between commits

basehead.description: A string specifying the base and head Git revisions to compare, in the format `BASE_REF...HEAD_REF`. `BASE_REF` and `HEAD_REF` can be commit SHAs, branch names, or tags. For example, `main...develop` or `v1.0.0...v1.1.0`.
basehead.title: Basehead

name.description: The optional full path, relative to the repository root, of a specific dependency manifest file (e.g., `package-lock.json`, `pom.xml`). If provided, the diff will be scoped to this file.
name.title: Name

owner.description: The username or organization name that owns the repository. This field is not case-sensitive.

tools.name: Get all commonly used licenses
tools.description: Retrieves a list of commonly used software licenses from GitHub, optionally filtering for 'featured' licenses whose specific selection criteria by GitHub may vary.

featured.description: If true, filters for licenses that GitHub considers 'featured', such as popular or recommended licenses. Note: The exact criteria for 'featured' are not explicitly documented by GitHub for this endpoint and behavior may vary.
featured.title: Featured

page.description: The page number for the set of results to retrieve (must be an integer starting from 1). Used for paginating through the list of licenses.
page.title: Page

per_page.description: The number of license results to return per page (must be an integer between 1 and 100, inclusive). Used for paginating through the list of licenses.
per_page.title: Per Page

inputParameters.title: GetAllCommonlyUsedLicensesRequest
inputParameters.description: Request schema for retrieving a list of commonly used licenses from GitHub.

data.description: A dictionary where keys are unique license string identifiers (e.g., 'mit', 'apache-2.0') and values are objects detailing each corresponding license. Each license object typically includes: 'key' (the unique identifier itself), 'name' (full name of the license), 'spdx_id' (SPDX identifier), 'url' (API URL to get this license's details), 'node_id' (GraphQL node ID), 'html_url' (URL to the license text, often on choosealicense.com), 'description' (a brief summary), 'implementation' (guidance on how to use the license), 'permissions' (list of strings describing allowed actions), 'conditions' (list of strings describing obligations), 'limitations' (list of strings describing restrictions), and 'body' (the full text of the license).
data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

direction.description: Sort direction: `asc` (ascending) or `desc` (descending).
direction.title: Direction

filter.description: Filter by user interaction: `assigned` (issues assigned to the user), `created` (issues created by the user), `mentioned` (issues where the user is mentioned), `subscribed` (issues the user is subscribed to for updates), `repos` (all issues in repositories the user has access to, e.g., owned, member), or `all` (all issues the user can see, regardless of direct participation).

labels.description: Comma-separated label names; issues must match *all* specified labels (e.g., `bug,ui,@high`).
labels.title: Labels

page.description: Page number for paginated results.
page.title: Page

per_page.description: Number of results per page (maximum 100).
per_page.title: Per Page

since.description: Include issues last updated at or after this ISO 8601 timestamp (e.g., `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`).
since.title: Since

sort.description: Sort field for issues: `created` (by creation date), `updated` (by last update date), or `comments` (by number of comments).
sort.title: Sort

before.description: A pagination cursor. Returns activity items that occurred before this cursor. This cursor is typically obtained from the `Link` header in a previous API response. For more details, see GitHub's REST API documentation on "Using pagination in the REST API" and "Using Link headers".

per_page.title: Per Page

tools.name: Manage access control for organization codespaces
tools.description: Sets the Codespaces access control policy for a GitHub organization, determining which members can use them.

org.description: The name of the GitHub organization. This field is not case-sensitive.
org.title: Org

selected_usernames.description: A list of GitHub usernames who should have access to Codespaces. This field is required and used only when `visibility` is set to `selected_members`. Providing a list here will replace any existing list of selected usernames.
selected_usernames.title: Selected Usernames

visibility.description:
Defines which users can access Codespaces within the organization.
`disabled`: Codespaces are disabled for all users in the organization.
`selected_members`: Only users specified in `selected_usernames` can access Codespaces.
`all_members`: All members of the organization can access Codespaces.
`all_members_and_outside_collaborators`: All members and outside collaborators can access Codespaces.
visibility.title: Visibility

inputParameters.title: ManageAccessControlForOrganizationCodespacesRequest
inputParameters.description: Request model for managing Codespaces access control within an organization.

data.description: Response data, which is typically empty as a successful (HTTP 204) response has no body.
data.title: Data

error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

tools.name: Create a pull request
tools.description: DEPRECATED: Use `create_a_pull_request` instead. Creates a pull request, requiring existing `base` and `head` branches.

base.description: The name of the branch you want the changes pulled into. This must be an existing branch on the current (target) repository. You cannot submit a pull request to one repository that requests a merge to a base branch of another repository.
base.title: Base

body.description: The detailed description or contents of the pull request.
body.title: Body
examples: This PR introduces a new feature that does X, Y, and Z.
Fixes #42 by addressing the off-by-one error.

draft.description: Indicates whether the pull request should be created as a draft. Draft pull requests cannot be merged until marked as ready for review.
draft.title: Draft

head.description: The name of the branch where your changes are implemented. For cross-repository pull requests, namespace `head` with the source owner and branch, like `username:branch`.
head.title: Head

head_repo.description: The name of the repository (e.g., 'octocat/Hello-World') where the changes in the pull request were made. This field is required for cross-repository pull requests if both the source and target repositories are owned by the same organization but are different repositories.
head_repo.title: Head Repo

issue.description: The number of an existing issue in the repository to convert into a pull request. If provided, the issue's title and body may be used for the pull request. Required if `title` is not specified.
issue.title: Issue

maintainer_can_modify.description: Indicates whether maintainers of the upstream repository can modify the pull request. This is primarily relevant for pull requests originating from forks.
maintainer_can_modify.title: Maintainer Can Modify

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. This name is not case-sensitive.
owner.title: Owner

repo.description: The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This name is not case-sensitive.
repo.title: Repo

title.description: The title of the new pull request. Required unless `issue` is specified.
title.title: Title

inputParameters.description: Request schema for `CreateAPullRequest`

data.title: Data

error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

tools.name: Create a review for a pull request
tools.description: DEPRECATED: Use `create_a_review_for_a_pull_request` for creating pull request reviews; supports `PENDING` for drafts and comment positioning.

body.description: Review's main body text; required if `event` is `REQUEST_CHANGES` or `COMMENT`.
body.title: Body

comments.description: Inline draft review comments. Each object requires `path` (relative file path) and `body` (comment text). Optionally, specify `line` (or `start_line` for multi-line), and `side` (or `start_side`) for diff location. `position` is deprecated; use `line`. Example: `[{'path': 'file.py', 'line': 10, 'body': 'Refactor this.'}]`
comments.title: Comments

body.description: The text of the comment
body.title: Body

line.description: The line number in the diff to comment on (required for single-line comments)
line.title: Line

path.description: The relative path to the file being commented on
path.title: Path

side.description: The side of the diff to place the comment on (LEFT or RIGHT)
side.title: SideEnm

start_line.description: The start line number for multi-line comments
start_line.title: Start Line

start_side.description: The side of the diff to start a multi-line comment on
start_side.title: SideEnm

commit_id.description: SHA of the commit to review; defaults to the latest pull request commit. Outdated SHAs may lead to stale comments.
commit_id.title: Commit Id

event.description: Review action type (`APPROVE`, `REQUEST_CHANGES`, `COMMENT`); if omitted, review is `PENDING` and requires later submission.
event.title: EventEnm

owner.description: Username of the account owning the repository (case-insensitive).
owner.title: Owner

pull_number.description: Identifying number of the pull request.
pull_number.title: Pull Number

repo.description: Repository name, without the `.git` extension (case-insensitive).
repo.title: Repo

inputParameters.title: CreateAReviewForAPullRequestRequest
inputParameters.description: Request schema for `CreateAReviewForAPullRequest`

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

tools.name: Create a review comment for a pull request
tools.description: DEPRECATED: Creates a review comment on a pull request's diff. Use `create_a_review_comment_for_a_pull_request` instead.

body.description: Text content of the review comment.
body.title: Body

commit_id.description: SHA of the commit for the comment. Using an outdated `commit_id` can misplace the comment if lines change.
commit_id.title: Commit Id

in_reply_to.description: ID of an existing review comment to reply to. If provided, other location parameters (except `body`) are ignored.
in_reply_to.title: In Reply To

line.description: **Required unless `subject_type` is 'file'**. Line number in the diff for the comment; for multi-line, this is the last line of the range.
line.title: Line

owner.description: Account owner of the repository (not case sensitive).
owner.title: Owner

path.description: Relative path of the file for the comment.
path.title: Path

position.description: **Deprecated: Use `line` instead.** Position in the diff hunk for the comment (not the file line number).
position.title: Position

pull_number.description: Identifier of the pull request.
pull_number.title: Pull Number

repo.description: Repository name without the `.git` extension (not case sensitive).
repo.title: Repo

side.description: Side of the diff (`LEFT` or `RIGHT`) for the comment in a split diff view; for multi-line comments, refers to the last line of the range.
side.title: Side

start_line.description: **Required for multi-line comments unless `in_reply_to` is used.** First line in the diff for a multi-line comment.
start_line.title: Start Line

start_side.description: **Required for multi-line comments unless `in_reply_to` is used.** Starting side of the diff (`LEFT` or `RIGHT`) for a multi-line comment.
start_side.title: Start Side

subject_type.description: Level of the comment target: `line` (specific line) or `file` (entire file). Defaults to `line` if not provided.
subject_type.title: Subject Type

inputParameters.title: CreateAReviewCommentForAPullRequestRequest
inputParameters.description: Request schema for `CreateAReviewCommentForAPullRequest`

data.description: Details of the newly created pull request review comment.
data.title: Data

error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

merge_commit_message.title: Merge Commit Message

merge_commit_title.description: The default title for a merge commit. `PR_TITLE` uses the pull request's title. `MERGE_MESSAGE` uses a classic title like 'Merge pull request #123 from branch-name'.
merge_commit_title.title: Merge Commit Title

name.description: The name of the repository. Must be unique within your account. Will be used in the repository URL (github.com/username/repo-name). Can only contain alphanumeric characters, hyphens, underscores, and periods.

private.description: Whether the repository is private (true) or public (false).

squash_merge_commit_message.description: The default message for a squash merge commit. `PR_BODY` uses the pull request's body. `COMMIT_MESSAGES` uses the branch's commit messages. `BLANK` results in a blank commit message.
squash_merge_commit_message.title: Squash Merge Commit Message

squash_merge_commit_title.description: The default title for a squash merge commit. `PR_TITLE` uses the pull request's title. `COMMIT_OR_PR_TITLE` uses the commit's title (if only one commit) or the pull request's title (if multiple commits).
squash_merge_commit_title.title: Squash Merge Commit Title

The notification setting the team has chosen. Editing teams without specifying this parameter leaves `notification_setting` intact.
  - `notifications_enabled`: Team members receive notifications when the team is @mentioned.
  - `notifications_disabled`: No one receives notifications for team @mentions.

To remove an existing parent team relationship and make this a top-level team, explicitly pass `null` for this field (e.g., by setting this parameter to Python `None`). If this parameter is not provided in the request, the current parent team, if any, remains unchanged.
parent_team_id.title: Parent Team Id

privacy.description:
The desired privacy level for the team. Editing teams without specifying this parameter leaves `privacy` intact. When a team is nested, the `privacy` for parent teams cannot be `secret`.
  - For a non-nested team:
    - `secret`: Visible only to organization owners and members of this team.
    - `closed`: Visible to all members of this organization.
  - For a parent or child team:
    - `closed`: Visible to all members of this organization.
privacy.title: Privacy

team_slug.description: The team's unique slug identifier (typically URL-friendly version of team name).

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

tools.name: Upload an analysis as sarif data
tools.description: Uploads a gzipped and Base64 encoded SARIF file to a GitHub repository for a specific commit and reference; use `checkout_uri` if SARIF paths are absolute.

checkout_uri.description: The base URI of the checkout directory as it appears in the SARIF file. This property is used to convert absolute file paths to relative paths, enabling alerts to be correctly mapped to their location in the repository.
checkout_uri.title: Checkout Uri

commit_sha.description: The SHA of the commit to which the analysis you are uploading relates. Must be a 40-character Git SHA.
commit_sha.title: Commit Sha

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. This is case-insensitive.
owner.title: Owner

ref.description: The full Git reference for the analysis, formatted as `refs/heads/<branch name>`, `refs/tags/<tag>`, `refs/pull/<number>/merge`, or `refs/pull/<number>/head`.
ref.title: Ref

repo.description: The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This is case-insensitive.
repo.title: Repo

sarif.description: A Base64 encoded string of a gzipped SARIF file. For more information, see '[SARIF support for code scanning](https://docs.github.com/code-security/secure-coding/sarif-support-for-code-scanning)'.
sarif.title: Sarif
examples: eJzVst... (actual gzipped and Base64 encoded SARIF content)

started_at.description: The timestamp indicating when the analysis run began, in ISO 8601 format: `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`.
started_at.title: Started At

tool_name.description: Name of the tool that generated the analysis. GitHub defaults this to "API" if omitted. A tool GUID in the SARIF can be used for filtering alerts.
tool_name.title: Tool Name

validate.description: Specifies whether the uploaded SARIF file should be validated against the code scanning specifications. This is useful for integrators to ensure their SARIF files are correctly processed and rendered by GitHub.
validate.title: Validate

inputParameters.title: UploadAnAnalysisAsSarifDataRequest
inputParameters.description: Request schema for `UploadAnAnalysisAsSarifData`

data.description: A dictionary containing the response from the GitHub API. Upon successful upload, this typically includes an `id` for the SARIF analysis, which can be used to track its status or retrieve details later. It may also include an `url` to access the analysis.
data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

tools.name: Upload a release asset
tools.description: Tool to upload a binary asset to an existing GitHub release. Use when you need to attach files like installers or backups to a release programmatically.

asset.title: FileUploadable
asset.description: Binary file to upload as the release asset. The 'name' property of FileUploadable sets the filename (e.g., 'installer.zip'). Provide 's3key' obtained via a prior file staging/upload action. Alternatively, you may omit this and use 'local_file_path'.

content_type.description: Media type of the asset, for example 'application/zip'.
content_type.title: Content Type

label.description: Short description for the asset; displayed instead of filename.
label.title: Label

local_file_path.description: Absolute path to a local file to upload as the asset. If provided, the action will read raw bytes from this path instead of using the FileUploadable 's3key'.
local_file_path.title: Local File Path

owner.description: Account owner of the repository; not case sensitive.
owner.title: Owner

repo.description: Repository name without the .git extension; not case sensitive.
repo.title: Repo

data.description: Data from the action execution
data.title: Data

browser_download_url.description: Browser-friendly download URL for this asset.
browser_download_url.title: Browser Download Url

created_at.description: ISO 8601 timestamp when the asset was created.
created_at.title: Created At

digest.description: Checksum digest of the uploaded asset.
digest.title: Digest

download_count.description: Number of times the asset has been downloaded.
download_count.title: Download Count

label.description: Short label of the asset, if provided.
label.title: Label

name.description: Filename of the uploaded asset.
name.title: Name

node_id.description: Global GraphQL node ID for this asset.
node_id.title: Node Id

size.description: Size of the asset in bytes.
size.title: Size

updated_at.description: ISO 8601 timestamp when the asset was last updated.
updated_at.title: Updated At

uploader.description: The user who uploaded this asset.
uploader.title: Uploader

html_url.description: GitHub profile URL for the uploader.
html_url.title: Html Url

id.description: Unique user ID of the uploader.
id.title: Id

node_id.description: Global GraphQL node ID of the uploader.
node_id.title: Node Id

site_admin.description: Whether the uploader is a GitHub site admin.
site_admin.title: Site Admin

url.description: API URL for the uploader.
url.title: Url

url.description: API URL for this asset.
url.title: Url

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful
